sect1.title: Kernel: Page-Cache Limit
sect1.remark: The presentation of Problem/Solution is on one hand quite useful, on the other it is very inconsistent with the rest of this chapter. - sknorr, 2016-02-12

listitem.para: The kernel swaps out rarely accessed memory pages to use freed memory pages as cache to speed up file system operations, for example during backup operations.

&netweaver; and &hana; use large amounts of memory for accelerated access to business data. Parts of this memory are rarely accessed. When a user request needs to access paged-out memory, the response time is poor. It is even worse when an SAP application running on Java incurs a Java garbage collection: The system starts heavy page-in (disc I/O) activity and has a poor response time for an extended period of time.

&sles4sap; includes a kernel tuning option that allows the system administrator to limit the amount of page cache that the kernel uses when there is competition between application memory and page-cache. This option tells the kernel that when the page cache is filled to the configured limit, application memory is more important and should thus not be paged out. No pages will be paged out if the memory footprint of the workload plus the configured page-cache limit do not exceed the amount of physical RAM in the system.

sect1.para: SAP applications require many open ports and port ranges in the firewall. The exact numbers depend on the selected instance. For more information, see the documentation provided to you by SAP.

sect1.title: Configuring HANA-Firewall
sect1.para: To simplify setting up a firewall for &hana;, install the package HANA-Firewall. Whereas standard &susefirewall; allows only three zones (internal, DMZ, and external), HANA-Firewall enables you to configure more zones to accommodate all running &hana; instances.
HANA-Firewall works by adding rule sets to your existing &susefirewall; configuration.
HANA-Firewall consists of the following parts:

formalpara.title: &yast; Module SAP HANA Firewall
formalpara.para: Allows configuring, applying, and reverting firewall rules for &hana; from a graphical user interface.

formalpara.title: Command-Line Utility hana-firewall
formalpara.para: Allows applying and reverting the configured firewall rules for &hana;.

listitem.para: If you prefer, you can configure the rule sets using the configuration file at /etc/sysconfig/hana-firewall instead of using &yast;.

formalpara.title: Service hana-firewall
formalpara.para: Ensures that configured firewall rules for &hana; are kept.

step.para: Make sure the &hana; database/databases that you want to configure a firewall for are correctly installed.

important.title: Multi-Tenant Databases

You need to switch to the directory /etc/hana-firewall.d, otherwise the rule file for the new service will be created in a place where it cannot be used.
The script will ask a number of questions: Importantly, it will ask for TCP and UDP port ranges that need to be opened.
